reviews.review_text: When I first played The Witcher, I was in middle school and I had pirated the game. Like most middle schoolers, I wasn’t very smart and the only thing I really looked for in a game was how many bad guys I could murder. I finished the game and quickly forgot about it. Only after I was in college did I realize to the full extent the awful choices that I had made during my first playthrough of The Witcher. My crimes were beyond description. I killed street dogs and innocent travelers just to loot 2 orens worth of stuff from their corpses. I slept with women and promptly abandoned them to be murdered by angry mobs or overzealous knights. I killed a fellow witcher. I walked away from a chance to have a happy family with a woman who loved me in order to sleep with my sex buddy sorceress who I thought looked hotter. I helped commit mass genocide, murdering dozens of non-humans fighting for freedom.  By chance I happened to see The Witcher: Enhanced Edition on sale during Steam Summer Sale 2014. I took it as a sign from heaven. Lord Gaben the Redeemer was speaking to me through my computer, offering me a chance to atone for my sins of the first playthrough. Now I could do what I had not done in middle school. I would uphold justice and help the weak. I would be the hero that Vizima needed, but not the one it deserved. And I could do it with 75% off. I clicked buy and my $1.99 ascended to the heavens while the face of Lord Gaben smiled down upon me.

The Witcher was released almost nine years ago and regularly goes on sale for a couple of dollars or less. The question for today's player isn't so much if the game is worth your money but rather if it's worth your time. The answer, in true Witcher fashion, isn't entirely black and white.  The game for me was, overall, enjoyable. The combat system is unique, and regardless of it's mixed reviews, I found it to be a serviceable and even somewhat cool RPG combat system. The finishers tend to get a bit repetitive but add a nice, and gruesome, touch. Although the main story isn't incredibly epic, the decisions that you make along the way feel like they are, and have a significant impact on certain characters fates. I particularly enjoyed the economic system in the early to mid-game, when you actually feel like you need to put in work to earn those Orens, because everyone has their hand in your coin pouch, and everything you want to accomplish has a price. Unfortunately this fades towards the end of the game as there simply isn't anything left to buy and no one left to bribe. Graphically the game doesn't look bad, it’s got its hiccups sure, but nothing that interferes with playability.  Geralt, despite being one of the ugliest human beings I've ever seen in this particular game, somehow manages to slay more women than monsters--quite an accomplishment considering aptitude for his profession. The dude simply can't miss, and it's undeniably entertaining to see just how many naughty cards you can collect. It also adds an interesting layer of complexity to Geralt's ongoing romance with a certain red-haired sorceress. No matter how serious their relationship tries to become, the White Wolf simply can't stop banging other women. Relationships are hard. Players unfamiliar with the series may find Geralt's character at first take to be bland, dull, or flat out boring. However, once you begin to understand his complexities, his sarcastic and cynical nature, and his convictions, you'll surely come to appreciate this incredibly rich and interesting character as so many others have.  The world map by today's standards is pretty small but the game easily has 50 hours of content. This translates into A TON of backtracking. By the end of Chapter II I was more familiar with the streets of Vizima than my own neighborhood, which is great because the mini-map is zoomed in way too far and makes navigation a little frustrating. I often found myself needing to open the world map just to find a house that was actually ten feet away. NPCs carry on with their daily lives, which at first seems pretty cool, until you're searching for one for twenty minutes because he's not getting drunk at the inn for once and he's slipped off his magical RPG quest-tracking bracelet. Because Geralt's a Witcher, monster contracts play a role in the game, unfortunately most of them are simply kill X number of Y monster and turn in their eyes/teeth/skins/whatever. One of them even has Geralt collecting flowers...??! That's like hiring Agent 47 to assassinate a weed in your garden.   The recycling of NPC textures is somewhat distracting but doesn't ruin the experience. Expect though, to see the same fat guy, skinny guy, and half-naked hooker models reused over and over throughout your adventure. The game also suffers painfully from a gear shortage. I found myself using the same armor and two swords throughout most of my adventure. The difficulty on normal is average, as it should be, but does have some frustrating moments. Too many enemy groups have to ability to stun-lock Geralt, causing him to stagger like a drunken derelict as you helplessly pound on your peripherals for way longer than any doctor recommends.   Mini-games are present; dice poker has you playing poker by rolling dice instead of drawing cards and is ok at first but you'll quickly get tired of it. There are also fist fights which pit Geralt against an array of fighters of supposedly increasing difficulty, however, once you figure out the somewhat wonky fighting mechanics you'll be able to beat the crap out of even the strongest opponents with virtually no effort. Overall, the mini-games felt like they could have been left out and, much like me at a party, no one would have even noticed they weren’t there.   Now, we circle back to our original question; is The Witcher worth your time in 2016? As a fan of The Witcher 3 I certainly found it to be worth mine. Despite it's age and other concerns, the game is still pretty darn good. If you're completely new to the series it would seem like the obvious place to start but I would actually recommend starting with the Witcher 3 and working back to this one. Many may not agree, but the game is 50 hours long and sometimes feels like a slog. If you're not already invested in these stories and characters, and the lore of this world, playing this game first, as a contemporary player, could potentially turn you off to the entire franchise and that would be a shame. If you're a fan of the Witcher 3, like me, and want to experience more content from this world, then there's no reason not to give this game a spin.  Final score: 7/10 RECOMMENDED.  Thank you for reading and good hunting

The Witcher is such a janky, unpolished game; a game you can clearly tell was made by total amateurs. But under the copy pasted NPCs, stiff animations and wonky as hell combat you're left with one of the most ambitious games of 2007 and the banging introduction to one of the best new WRPG series in the past 10 years.  In the game, you play as Geralt of Rivia who is a witcher, a mutant monster hunter-for-hire, who finds himself caught in the middle of a conspiracy of assassinating kings and ushering in the end times. The games story leads you hoping around the small country of Temeria: from swampy villages overrun by zealotry to a walled city plagued by a literal disease and corruption. What seperates The Witcher from many WRPGs is it's take on morality and choices: while many games go for a very binary 'Good Cop vs. Bad Cop' approach marked by convient color-coded meters coughMassEffectcough, TW1 instead places a heavy emphasis on grey morality. As it says on the marketing blurb, there are no hardline good guys and paragons of virtue: everyone is very flawed in various ways and it's up to you to decide how you will approach or ally with them. While there's alot of unneeded fluff to some of the story (Chapters 1 and 4, specifically) but ultimately every moment and character feels incredibly memorable and well-writen. Friends like Thaler, Dandelion, Zoltan and enemies like Javed, the Professor and Salamandrian bandits all add lots of life and personality to the setting. Even if you started with The Witcher 3 and are spoiled by the overall higher quality... everything , you'll begin to see the same ingredients that made the third game so great.   And then there's the bad. When I say The Witcher is jank, it is J A N K. Geralt moves faster going forward than moving backward or strafing left and right. Combat isn't like a typical action RPG where you keep clicking to attack, but instead it's like a psuedo-music game where you must left-click on time. Positioning is also a pain in the butt because of said movement control jankiness. I think the gameplay is the biggest issue with the first Witcher because, to be quite honest, CDPR really didn't seem to know what they were doing as this was literally their first game. This can be a huge deterrent for new gamers, especially those coming from the much more refined TW3.   But despite that, I still highly recommend playing this game if you're looking for a great WRPG that isn't made by either Bethesda or Bioware (both of which I think are slacking but that's another story for another time). It's flaws are less the result of malice and more the result of inexperience and if you really want to get into The Witcher and see how everything began, I can't recommend any other place to begin but the first game.

The Witcher is a strange beast. At this point, everyone knows how beloved The Witcher III instantly became, and everyone knows it as a true force to be reckoned with in terms of Western RPGs. So, to preface, the most important thing about getting into The Witcher 1 is to remind yourself that this is not The Witcher III. Not at all. The Witcher is clunky, aged, and features some questionable design choices. But at the same time, it features some great dialogue, story, and setpieces.  Gameplay -- The hardest part about getting through The Witcher is, regrettably, actually playing it. The combat is a very simple click in rhythm style affair with two swords for different enemy types and three fighting styles for each sword. It's not horribly involved, and it's usually more time consuming and frustrating than it is fun. You are also outfitted with 'signs', an alternative for magic. These signs vary in usefulness, and I personally didn't use them a lot, with the exception of Igni. However, I may be underselling them, and they may very well be overpowered. I'm not sure. Along with this, the game also emphasizes the creation and consumption of potions, which the game will be nearly unbeatable without. As your own personal skill does little to influence the battles of this game, potions will be mandatory as a crutch. The leveling system is also unique, in that every level you get a handful of skill points to put into various skill trees. But, these skills are divided into bronze, silver, and gold levels. It takes many, many levels to get gold skills, and I didn't even see any until the final act. This may be my own fault for not completing every single side quest in the game, but the pacing does feel off. To level up, create potions, or pass the time, you must meditate, which requires a fire. It works.  I would be remiss if I didn't address one of my biggest problems with the game. The quest/level design is designed in such a way that you will spent the majority of your time running from one end of the act area to the other, repeatedly. This is a problem in almost every act, barring IV and V where this is slacked a little. Act I is designed as a ring shaped road with various buildings and divergent paths from it, and it seems every quest phase will take place on whatever the opposite end of the ring you're at is. Same thing with acts II and III, which both take place in the exact same location (albeit with new locations added for act III), where you must even go so far as to take a ferry ride to another area just to complete some basic quests. It's monotonous, and it's easily the most glaring fault of the game. Rather than true gameplay, it's time filler with no actual value added. For being a game, the actual gameplay is not exactly exceptional.  Story -- This is where the game actually begins to shine. This game forces you to make a lot of morally ambiguous decisions that can radically alter how the story plays out. Do you, a monster slayer, side with a monster for the sake of doing what's right? Or do you acknowledge that slaying said beast is your purpose in life, and ignore your personal feelings to do what must be done? Several decisions of this caliber are thrusted towards you, and I sat staring at my monitor more than once, unable to make a choice. For the most part, the plot itself is gripping. It's what kept me playing and convinced me to keep coming back. I will say that it does hit a point where the story becomes almost stupid, but the side quests and implications of character actions save it from being a complete game killer. The dialogue is a little weird, but appealing. Many characters use modern slang and sayings despite the game taking place in an 11th century fantasy setting. It's a little jarring, but not wholly unpleasant.  Graphics/Sound -- The graphics are, as one would expect, aged. There are a lot of reused character models, and a lot of these models are downright corny. The old woman model is especially eyebrow raising. Some of the areas in the game are crafted quite well, however, despite the level design mishaps referenced earlier. The swamps feel appropriately foreboding. The city is as dingy and unfortuante as you would expect. Sunlit fields are contrasted with noonwraiths, adding a troubling element of horror to an otherwise beautiful scene. These areas allow the game to truly breathe. The sound design is rather hit and miss. Some of the voice acting is as overbaked as the character models, where other voice acting flourishes. Geralt himself is exceptionally well voiced, sounding both apathetic to the world and caring at the same time. It's subtle, but effective. The music is serviceable, but nothing that will make you run out and buy the soundtrack any time soon.  As a whole, The Witcher is really a developmental step for CD Projekt Red, as one would assume. It sets up the basis of some general mechanics that will be carried on through future The Witcher titles, but it misses the target a lot as well. That said, it perfectly sets up the rest of the franchise, and has some great moments that will keep you playing. I do recommend it, but do be warned that it is not the masterpiece the newer games are.

The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is the most underrated game ever. It's perfection. The graphics are amazing: if you compare with Dragon Age they are so much better even though this game is older. The music is a masterpiece and fits perfectly everywhere ... it really makes you feel like the places actually exist and gives the game a very unique and special feeling. The characters are very interesting and you want to know more and more about them all the time (very much as in Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn). The story is also awesome ... I don't want to spoil anything but it really is great.  If you like RPGs then buy this game. It's a masterpiece and one of the best RPGs ever made (Baldur's Gate II and Morrowind are the only RPGs I recon beats this game).

If there is a game that deserve a remaster, The Witcher is definitly one of them, using all that the devs learned in the last 2 games of the series and finally put the gameplay at par with the rest of the game, but even at this point, a game that deserve your attention bc it still worth the time by far.

A Fine RPG Whose Strengths Outweigh Its Weaknesses

The first witcher game in the popular series.  Pros: Graphics still hold up today for a 2007 game  Voice acting is pretty good though im not sure about geralt's voice....  User interface at first seems complex but very easy to use (apparently before a few updates it was bad)  Combat at first also seems to be awkward but its not once you get use to it, ( to explain it, you click the mouse once and then wait for the cursor to flash yellow and click again, not hard at all)  Story is really good as well as the side quests. Decent mini games with 'Dice poker' and 'Fist fights'  Lots of interesting characters, monsters and areas.  Cons:  Game will not work on windows 10 (seems to run fine for the first few chapters, waiting for confirmation on the last few chapters)  When you need to use the flame torch sometimes geralt randomly puts it away (annoying as hell in dark crypts and tombs) though you mainly use 'cat' potions that allow you to see in the dark.  Lots of people report random crashes which is most frequent on windows 10 as i mentioned although on chapter 5 i myself experience a few random crashes on windows 8.1 but they were very rare for me and didnt halt my playing experience.  Overall decent action rpg game people tend to complain about the combat and user interface but i think these reviews that mention this were written before the 'enhanced update' came into play, honestly no where near as bad as people are making out.  7/10

This game is extraordinary. I purchased this game before reading the books, but played it after I read them and that added so much to the already great story... Anyway, the game itself is just great. Although the controls are a bit oldschool, after you ge used to it, there's nothing in the way for you to enjoy the story of a freshly resurrected witcher Geralt of Rivia, which takes place in a very nicely made city of Wyzima and its surroundings. Although the game is old and so are the graphics, it's just beautiful and with the option of importing saves to the second Witcher, it really makes every decision important. It can also be quite difficult, so remember to save, because there's nothing more unnerving than having to fight through loads of monsters and talking to a lot of people for the second time. So, the main question is: would I recommend this game? The answer is not really difficult. Of course, andif you read the books, then it's almost necessary for you to give this old jewel a go.

WOW!! What a great RPG. This is one of the rare cases where your actions, decisions and choices count on the outcome of the game. You will definetely craft your own experience with this one, even though you might see the outcoming of your deeds only in the later part of the game. This game is highly recommended to anybody, who likes good story telling, interesting quests and side-quests as well as enjoyable mini-games (fistfighting + dice-poker). Go for it NOW!!!!

This game is one of my favourite games ever and i personally think it even beats the second witcher. The witcher 1 has one of the best stories i have ever personally experienced, and without spoiling to much you will be shocked by the twists and turns it takes throughout the 30+ hour story. It features theifs, elves, humans, dwarfs, monsters and much more which it ties together nicely with an overarching plot about politics, racism and much more.  As a small tip i would say try to do all the sidemissions, they lend a great bit of depth to the main plot and even the smaller quests will play their role in some way later on. The combat system can be a bit basic and the pace is a little bit off sometimes but overall this game is amazing and you owe it to yourself to play it!

Before play I think it would be liked Skyrim but after played for a while I realized it is more complex than Skyrim in anyway like UI, quest marker, gameplay... So anyway, it worths for a try. 10/10 would played more.

PROS: - Geralt's character development (with quite original method of talents) - potion making (includes picking of herbs, harvesting jaws of vampires etc.) - moral choices reflecting in changing attitudes of other characters - multitude of quests - some parts are really intense - deep, immersive story - nice music, beautiful landscapes, amazing architecture - seducing women is kind of fun - becoming master of dice poker and fist fighting is also kind of fun - original monsters  MEH: - somewhere midgame you get a lot of bothersome 'run here, talk, run there, talk' quests - you need to adjust to game's combat system - first 30-90 minutes of the game are kind of boring  CONS: - you don't get to use many weapons or armors, because other weapons than swords are not usable in witcher battle styles making them ineffective especially later in the game - after you start feeling which skills are important and focus on developing them, fighting becomes quite easy  Overall: you need to bite the bullet and endure the first hour of the game. After that you get a really good, immersive RPG with damn good story and lots of locations.
Great game if you can look past the dated graphics and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat.
Even after all these years, the game still worth it. Best play it before the 2nd and 3rd game.

I remember playing this game 7 years ago, and yet when I started playing it again, the story was different. Instead of your usual linear RPGs, or those who have choices but they barely make any impact ingame, in The Witcher, everything you do has an impact on - the story, enemies and others. It feels great! Few games have ever achieved this level of detail.  Everything you do has an outcome, so not only this game has a high rate of re-playability, it will suprise you on your second run how things go different.  Also if you are a big  pervert  like me, you also will enjoy the sexual theme going in this game(infact in the book Geralt, the main hero, bangs anything that moves and is female apparently).  Well written story/ies, very original and distinct from what we are used to, the only downside is the combat system, but I got used to it.  One of the best RPGs out there indeed! I highly recommend you to try it and I tip my hat to CD Projekt RED.

Good: Graphics hold up decently given the age of it Atmosphere and sounds were nice Story and choices given to the character Depth and amount of gameplay  Bad: Combat Boss fights  Ultimately it was a good game, but I'd recommend you skip to The Witcher 2, and come back to this if you really want to know the story better.

My 50 hours of game-gasm! 9/10  Gameplay: This game is really fun to play. Especially when you immerse yourself in it. Story is just plane-awesome. Even some side quest have some connection with the main quest. side quests are not 'Must' in this game but they are as fun as main quest. most of side quest can be done through main quest, so it's not a bother to your experience. Dialogues are plane AWESOME. Best in my book. Your choices DO matter. even better then 'walking dead' series.  Sound & music: it's awesome. though it can be a bit dull sometimes. but when you are in a battle, it keeps you on your toes.  Graphics: Let's just say for this generation gamer it is acceptable, for me it was always awesome. neat models with good textures and nice shadow maps (no self shadowing). it doesn't support Vsync or triple buffering but they can be done through RadeonPro or nvidia controls. post processing is a bit too pixelated and it's a little bothering.  Overal: This game is like an interactive book. It's a MUST for every rpg player or for someone who likes a good story.

I'm just going to put this out there that this was the best RPG I have ever played hands down. I do not really play many RPGs and never really played any, but compared to other RPGs I have had time with, this was something else. Considering it came out in 2007 and provided me with over 30 hours of gameplay really amazed me. I was really proud with what CD Projekt Red had made here and obviously has evolved onto the current generation platforms. Of course with a great response outta me there were a few bumps in the road. Probably the most addressed here is the fighting mechanics. They aren't the best. Some can even say it sucked and I wouldn't blame them. Of course we should all factor in that it did come out in 2007 and this game was most likely on a tight budget (I am not saying it was on a tight budget but it seems likely). However the rest of the gameplay and plot does eclipse the bad fighting mechanics and really gives a you a great expeirence and also expands your 'book fanatsies' in terms of a monster riddled world (not sexual fantasies you uncultured cactus). In the end I would only change the fighting mechanics, and also the lack of direction in certain parts of the game, but can easily be figured out if you have a lot of gaming expeirence. Now at the time I am writing this review, The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is not available for individual download and is only in a Witcher bundle. I would wait until it is being sold on Steam individually because during Steam sale I paid $1.49 for it and it was a helluva deal and it gave me 30+ hours of gameplay. Definite Buy when it's not in that bundle because $5 doesn't hurt you terribly. Get the game and try it, and don't be like me with a scrub Mac with a crap GPU and can't play The Witcher 2 because of it..    *EDIT* I have beaten the second Witcher on Xbox 360 and surprisingly the first Witcher is the best of the two. First one offers more hours of gameplay, better music, more engaging story, but however the improved combat makes up in the second Witcher no doubt. Still recommend that you play both because the lore is unmatched in this series. Don't diss on the first one despite it's lack luster combat.  *Second Edit* Witcher 3 is the best RPG I've ever played now, but still give this game a shot if on sale.

Holy ♥♥♥♥! this game.... its freeking great!! sure it can be boring sometimes running around for the quests. but the story, it kept me entertained from start to finish. it took me about 2-3 weeks or 80 hours or so to complete the game. if you who ever reads this. Get the game. its just great :)

A beautiful game, even after 7 years. The Witcher is a dark and rather mature game. You get to make game-changing decisions that let you feel as though you are a part of the game.   The first chapter is rather slow, but it gives you time to experiment around and get a feel for the combat. Some of the game mechanics were not explained properly (such as the alchemy) and it took a bit of experimenting to get some things to work. The combat is not truly combat. You click when an icon appears and let your character do the rest. That, coupled with the fact that signs were too overpowered, led to a dull gameplay experience. However, all that are minor annoyances compared to what the game is truly capable of. The developers don't hold your hand and lead you through the entire game. Instead, they give you a few basic tutorials and leave the rest to experimentation. It also helps that alchemy is not a must (unless you're on higher difficulties).   All in all, the games treats you like an adult, leaving you with choices that feel real. You must choose between several choices based on your moral code, since nothing in this game is truly black and white. You would be hard pressed to decide sometimes and what you choose really just comes down to what you feel is right. The graphics are'nt amazing, and there are quite a few technical issues, but overall, I feel that this game is worth playing.
Definitely worth a giving a shot for this game.  Combat is maybe a bit odd/boring at the beginning, but after 3-5hours playing i found myself enjoying it.  9/10 from me.
Simply one of the most MATURE and INVOLVING RPGs in the steam library. Amazing gameplay, a choice system that will make you think of what may come, in a few words: get IT.

Brilliant game. Combat can be a little clunky, and the second chapter drags on, but nonetheless a great effort. The world of The Witcher is so finely crafted that you forget it has generic elves and dwarves. I believe that there is a point to this, that it can take standard fantasy elements and make them feel different. The gameplay has a lot of unique elements. You really have to tailor your equipment to each situation, but it doesn't feel like busy work.  This game is a must play.

Well, I just finished my first play through of this game... I feel a bit empty inside and conflicted on so many levels that I almost want to replay the game right now.  This gem of a game has such a real feel of choice and the consequences thereof. To that end, what I find refreshing is the lack of 'reputation' meter if you will. No immediate indication of a good or bad choice, that can only be given by our own inflection of the events that occur quite a bit further down the story line.  A very captivating, extremely enjoyable, intense gaming experience that is a must play for anyone who cares about story.
His name was Geralt of Rivia, he was a Witcher, a professional monster slayer...

The Witcher is a unique RPG. It eschews the standard 'fight monsters, save the world' formula and instead presents a detective story in 5 chapters. In the city of Vizima, you will unveil plots, woo ladies, play politics, negotiate settlements, and interrogate suspects. You'll make excursions to nearby swamps and cemeteries, so expect a fair dose of combat, but the core of the game is the investigation storyline.  Along the way, you'll face ethical quandaries and tough choices. Some choices can significantly affect the game's final chaper. Other choices might simply affect which girl you'll bed that evening...  I really enjoyed The Witcher. If I have any complaint, it's the pacing. As each chapter begins, you find yourself assaulted with quests. Eventually you'll figure out how quests turn on and off over the course of the game as you are able to advance each one. Turns out quests are actually highly intertwined plot elements.  Despite this complaint, it's a fresh and entertaining RPG.

After tying up every lose ends in the first of the witcher series and nearly logging in 50 hours into this game, I can say that I`m mentally exhausted. The Witcher is a fantastic rpg released back in 2007. It is a sequel to a series of fantasy novels centering around it's protagonist, Geralt of Rivia. In this game, after his apparent death in the novels. He awakes with amnesia and no recollection of his death nor the people in his life. After that he is launched on a quest of revenge as he remembers who he is.  One of the finest aspects of the Witcher is how it's quests are designed. You are never shown the consequences of your actions immediately. Instead, in later chapters of the game you see the results of your choices. This was done to prevent players simply reloading and not accepting the consequences of their actions. As a result your actions really do feel like they have weight, and it's rare to see this executed properly in a game.  There are of course negative aspects of the Witcher. Most people cite it's combat as the biggest drawback of the game. I'm inclined to agree, as I initially stopped playing just before finishing the prologue. My advice is to push on past the prologue as you start to really get into the game during it's first chapter. Eventually you will fall inlove with this game and it's timing based combat.

This is my Witcher story. I bought Witcher 3 because I wanted a new RPG to play; it was absolutely amazing. I only got through the first chapter and realized that I didn't want the experience to end so quickly so I decided to buy the first one and work my way through that and once done with that play through the second and then eventually move on to finish the third. That's how good this series is, if you're a fan of action RPG's with good stories like me, get the trilogy pack instead of this because if you can bear the combat/graphics (both of which are not THAT bad) of Witcher 1 you will definitely want to play the second and third. You will also enjoy them moreso because you have the background info of the first one.   So I loaded up Witcher 1 for the low cost of $9.99. First thing I noticed when I started playing the Witcher was the graphics, although extraordinary for 2007, after overclocking my GPU to play the third I was a little disappointed, but you can't ask for much when you backtrack to a game that came out 8 years ago!  The next thing I noticed was that this game's story is awesome. Cheesily enough, you start off with amnesia. However Geralt's lack of memory serves to push the story forward; Alongside the main conflict in the story, you are trying to find out about Geralt's past through quests and former friends. The best part about the story is that you actually can't wait to find out what happens next. This is the only rpg where I actually read the extra books and lore things you find in the game world because they serve the story so well. Where most RPG's push for progression by enticing you with new pieces of armor or weapons down the road, the Witcher puts you in a position where you actually want to find out what happens next and you don't really care about much else. However, at times, much of the story is told just by running back and forth and talking to various npcs - there gets to be a point when you want to just go out and smash some monster face. That leads me into one of the only two fair cons to find in this game (because you can't count the graphics of this game as a real con due to its age.)   My problems with this game are the combat and the lack of challenge. The fights remind me of 'Test Your Might' challenges from Mortal Kombat. You just wait until your sword turns yellow and then click, thats it. The whole combat system is click, wait a second or two, click, repeat. there's no real challenge or engagement to it. If you can't kill a monster you just reload and drink more buff potions. When I say there is no challenge to this game, I mean it. I always play games on their hardest difficulty just to feel like I really did beat the game. Even on the most difficult setting, I only had a few times where I struggled at all, and only one time I actually had any real difficulty. Chapter 1's boss fight is the only time I ever found myself struggling. Other than the boring combat and lack of challenge I don't have anything else to really gripe about. I mean the inventory system could have been better and there could have been more applications for alchemy but all in all this is a fantastic game. Sorry for the long winded review.

The game has many faults, though. Character assets are reused over and over with only a couple dozen unique characters in the game (surprisingly, though, this didn't irritate me as much as it might sound). Voice acting cutscenes are of a mediocre quality; not terrible but they've been surpassed elsewhere (like the subsequent entries in the series). Combat can be incredibly frustrating sometimes. For example, being stunned repeatedly by four wraiths to the point you cannot move or attack is maddening. It also felt that there were too many elements to the game, some of which can be (and ultimately have to be) ignored in favour of others. For example, I didn't get anywhere near maxing out my character (despite doing every quest) and never touched bombs. I also didn't feel all the signs were as useful as they could be; some easily overshadow others. Combat is generally quite easy (with a few exceptions).  I very much enjoyed the claustrophobic, urban setting of the first half of the game. When it changed setting in the second half I was, at first, relieved for a change of scenery but the following areas (while containing enjoyable quests) are overly large and it feels like all you're ever doing is walking from point to point (with, surprisingly - compared to earlier areas - few enemies to worry about). The game also has a somewhat awkward, somewhat rewarding epilogue sequence, a huge twist (if you're paying attention) and a cliffhanger ending.  Overall, I'd recommend it if you really want to play the entire trilogy. But if you're not that fussed, I'd probably suggest just reading up on what happens in the first game (and about its characters) and moving on to The Witcher 2 (where things improve and change drastically).

Skip to the recaps at the bottom of each one if you don't feel like reading it all  Pros:  Even though this game is almost a decade old it still holds a lot of core RPG and really compared to today's RPG still feels fresh. It has a story that changes based on your decisions, which leads to my next pro This series allows you to port your saves over from game to game. The decisions you make in Witcher 1 effect Witcher 2's story, and Witcher 2 carries over to Witcher 3. Not only does the decisions carry over, but the rare items I work so hard to aquire carry over too! I have began playing Witcher 2 and I was relieved to see my armor, swords, runes, potions, etc. Were all still with me! Using the F1, F2, F3 you can change from bird's eye view to over the shoulder view! GIving the player the choice to play by their preference.  You get to see boooooobs, and lots of them. Playing as a Witcher, a master of sword, magic, and alchemy set on hunting down a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sums it up BUT there is SO much content and unexpected twists.  Recap of pros: Well written story, carry over decisions and items throughout the series(Mass Effect got nothing on Witcher), gettin' some strange. (Seriously, Geralt get's laid in like the first 30 mins of the game)  CONS: When doing quest the NPC you need to talk to isn't always at the quest marker. So I'll be tracking it on my map, get there, and the NPC is no where to be found. That's because this game has a constant time cycle and simulates day and night. I simply have to wait (or rest to speed it up) till the certain time period for the NPC to show up again. There are a handful of character designs used for townsfolk, gang members, soldiers etc. So it kind of ruins the immerse effect sometimes. I cut Projekt Red a break though, I mean, when this game was developed it's probably the best they could do with the tech we had. Same with the voice acting too. The special NPC's are their own voice actors throughout the series, but the forementioned NPCs I feel like was 2 or 3 voice actors. All the bandits sound the same.  Compared to todays Open world RPG this game's world is small. Super small. I'm sure at the time this game was released it was very cutting edge but now adays it's going to feel like a small sandbox to the average RPG player. It's click, wait for the icon, click again. Though after powering up combo's it is fun to watch Geralt slash open an enemy.   Cons recap: Cloned NPC's, short on voice acting, unexplained missing quest NPCs (until undefined time of day), combat system is wierd compared to today's RPGs. This game is full of rich content, and is thriving with life. Most of the time.   Lets start with the good. It feels like an old timey RPG, with very simplistic, but addictive gameplay models. While the combat may not be supremely engaging, it can be very difficult at times, making preparation before a battle vital to surviving. All you need to do is master the almost, but not quite quicktime attack combat. The animations become more complex, and faster while requiring more timing and clicking with each improvement, making you feel like your moves are getting better and you feel all the more better.   Some potions are easy to make, some are not. Some are very helpful, some not so much. But each one can save your life in a dire situation. You can make a variety of bombs, potions, and oils/weapon enhancements. Some potions even make your character more powerful in general, giving him different abilities and ways to unlock special skills.  Time to talk about the negatives.  The negatives of this game are few, but can really screw with you. My system is very up-to-date and has been updated to keep with the times. However, I have experienced several blue screens through my playtime. I found this extremely odd and angering since no other game has done such a thing to me in the past. Glitches are slightly prevelant, but shouldn't cause too much trouble, and sometimes, the combat can be, at some times, meh. Sometimes, grinding is a factor you might have to use, going through a dangerous swamp to find a single herb for a swallow.   In conclusion, this is a great game, while rough around the edges, is very well made, and has fairly good graphics considering it was made in 2008. I strongly recommend this game, and remember, don't play the other witchers without starting from the beginning. Otherwise, nothing will make much sense in the long run.

The Witcher has a measure of flaws, to be sure. The combat isn't terribly challenging, some of the quests fall into the RPG tropes of 'fetch quests' or 'go here and kill x number of y', and I even ran into a few game-crashing bugs. Some of that may be simply age -- the game was released in 2007, and I finally played it eight years later -- but it's by no means perfect.  Having said that, I really did enjoy my time with Geralt of Rivia. While some of the quests in the game are 'FedEx' style trips, others are interesting investigations that are both interesting to play and get the player invested in the plot and characters. The game certainly has a story to tell, and is pushing you along that path -- but it's a good story, and one that I quite enjoyed. Sometimes I felt like the game was holding my hand a bit much, telling me where to go or what to do, but other times it let the lore and subtle clues fill in story details or render characters. And the world-builiding and story is really the best thing about this game. The titular character, in particular, is well-done. The game has introduced me to the works of Andrzej Sapkowski, and I look forward to finding out more about Geralt of Rivia in both the novels and CD Projekt RED's follow-up games.

A masterpiece!   The Witcher is the result of when a team of doctors work together to develop a video game. I will go on record saying that this is one of the absolute best games ever made. I've done 4 playthroughs total of this game and have not gotten bored. Witcher 1 has one of the most well written storylines of any RPG ever. A lot of RPG games trap themselves with moral decisions by making them purely good or evil choices. There's no black or white extremes in The Witcher though. Almost all characters in the entire world of the game have done good and bad things. It's this important difference that sets The Witcher apart so well. Some of the moral decisions and choices you have to make in the game will really cause you to stop for a moment and reflect on the situation. It's a game that has such powerful choices that it will literally make you reflect on your own morality. When does the means justify the ends? Where does somebody draw the line? Can bad things be jusitfied for a higher cause? These are a few of several questions you will ask yourself by the end of this masterpiece. The characters of the game are also unforgettable. Geralt the protagonist is a badass who you definitely can't help, but be a fan of. NPC's in the game are wonderful too and you can have discussions with them that add more to the world and story of The Witcher. Beyond the story, the gameplay is great too.   The combat system is a fun timing based system where you click at the right times to do combo attacks. In addition, you get signs which can knock down enemies, set up instant kills, light enemies on fire or trap them etc. Defeating enemies grants you EXP along with completing quests. You then level up after accumulating enough EXP and can distribute talent points into Geralt's abilities. Witcher's leveling system for increasing Geralt's strength is incredible. The amount of choices and possibilties are wonderful and every playthrough I always found myself trying out different builds. Witcher 1's combat is incredibly fun, but I won't lie it's far from a amazing combat system or one that will appeal to everyone. Some may just not like the timing nature of the combat system. It's not for everyone and you have been warned about this. Also, I mentioned quests. Witcher does have them.  They are found in the main story and sidequests. You can track quests to figure out where to go and it works very well. Witcher's sidequests are excellent though and a standard that RPG's should look up to. Almost every sidequest has a great story to it that upon completing it allows you to learn more about characters, the world and the story of the game itself. A sign of a well made sidequest is when the player doesn't just do it for a great reward in the game, but also for the content of the quest itself. That's another aspect Witcher excels in. There's as I mentioned a main story consisting of a prologue, epilogue and 5 chapters inbetween those two.   Each chapter you go through in the game is drastically different. In one you explore a village and help the residents there, but come to learn of some of the atrocities the residents have committed there. It ultimately reaches a climax where you must judge the villagers and decide their fates. In another chapter you go to meetings with nobles and powerful polticians where you form strong alliances with powerful people. Then there's a chapter in the game where you have to cooperate with a detective to figure out who committed a murder. The chapter has several different outcomes depending on the choices you make. Different events, dialogue and fights happen all depending on what choices you make. Ultimately, the game's story reaches it's climax in the epilogue and final chapter of the game Chapter 5. Chapter 5 is one of the most epic parts I've ever played in a RPG. Afterward, in the epilogue you confront the final antagonist of the game whom makes references to all the decisions you made throughout the game. Even me doing a sidequest in Chapter 1 was mentioned in the final confrontation of the game. Talk about a game truly changing even by doing small things. The replay value is immense.  In Witcher 1 there are three paths through the game. I won't spoil the three sides, but each one has different scenes, dialogues, locations and fights you experience in them. I'm no fanboy either though and will admit the game doesn't drastically change depending on your decisions. It does change a little, but you're not gonna see half of the entire game change because you aligned yourself with a different side in a future playthrough of the game. Still, the replay value is great and it's the choices making these little changes that make this wonderful game all the more satisfiying to play through. Last, the music.  The music of Witcher 1 is excellent. I'm not much of a fan of orchestrated music, but The Witcher really caught my attention with it's jaw droppingly good soundtrack. Some of the songs in the game such as The River of Life or several others really impressed me. In terms of voice acting, the game can be a mixed bag. Some voice acting is good, but some are not so good. Overall though, The Witcher is a masterpiece and one of my all time favorite games. I think that the world and story of the game are among the very best in any game ever. Beyond that, the combat is very fun, but admittedly is not going to be for everyone and is far from one of the most amazing battle systems ever. Last, the game has a great soundtrack and immense replay value with how choices impact the game. Any RPG fan owes it to themselves to experience this masterpiece of a game. I've finished 4 playthroughs of it and I will definitely play it more times through.  TLDR Version:  Pros: +One of the best stories and worlds in any RPG ever. +Great characters who are incredibly well developed. +Choices that affect how the game plays. With the Witcher 3 on the horizon, ready to cripple PCs like mine, some gamers out there may be wondering if they should give the series a shot starting with the first title. Despite it's problems, the Witcher 1 is great RPG. Here's why: your choices actually matter - No clear good or bad choices here, folks. It's all grey. You may even start to care about the world your in and those who inhabit it, all while being apart of an interesting story as it unfolds. The main story can take up to thirty to forty hours to complete if you really want to do everything the game has to offer.   And there is a lot to do: bar fights, gambling, bounties, fetch quests (of course), romances to pursue, and a few books to read.  Gameplay and presentation wise however, the Witcher 1 feels dated. The visuals appear blury at times and characters don't look quite right. The gameplay remains simple throughout the game; just time your clicks so that you can keep a combo going until your enemy falls. Bosses can feel extremely over powered at times too. The menus aren't problematic and don't take much to navigate.  Moving on to performance, with my first experience with this game I was running it on Vista. That was a mistake for sure, the game was prone to crash every two minutes or so, and every cutscene was a nail-bitter because I didn't know if I would see it through to the gameplay on the other side. I should also mention that my PC, - which is definitely capable of running the Witcher 1 at the time - when it was upgrade to Windows 7, experienced a lot less crashing.   If you really want to experience the Witcher 1 get it during a sale so that you won't feel like you've wasted your money if it doesn't run. And similar to Mass Effect, your save file can be transfered to the Witcher 2, so you can continue your adventure and deal with the consequences of whatever awful choices you had to make. It's not perfect, but the Witcher 1 is still a pleasure that any RPG fan won't want to miss out on.  Good hunting, witchers.

The Witcher is a game that I would easily recommend to anyone who plays on lower difficulties in order to concentrate on the story. The story in this game is fairly decent, and there are some moments when you may be surprised.  However, if you play the game on Hard, prepare yourself for frustration.  Not because the game is truly that challenging, but because some bugs can make it impossible to beat certain bosses unless you force yourself to farm areas multiple times for alchemy ingredients and xp.  For example, during the final stretch to the end of the game, I had a consistent bug that made it impossible to cast magic. If you're playing on Hard then magic is your friend. However, I was completely unable to cast magic, even with more than adequate endurance (spell casting resource) and no negative effects on me to prevent casting. This made the last three big fights of the game incredibly difficult, as you are easily beaten by bosses even if you have upgraded armor and potions.  If it weren't for the bugs this game has, this game would easily get an 8 out of 10 from me.   If you pick up this game, I'd recommend you play on Normal, as the bugs I experienced are common and make a Hard playthrough nigh impossible.  Pros: The story is interesting The universe is quite immersive There are plenty of sidequests that influence the main quests, so you're hardly ever questing just to quest You can feel the difference of difficulty as you level up and get stronger  Cons: Bugs are common in this game, gamebreaking or not There is a TON of running back and forth (travel gets much easier for a time in chapter 2 and 3) A Hard playthrough WILL frustrate you to no end if you get the magic bug There are frequent game crashes (at least 2 to 3 crashes for every few hours of gameplay. Seems to be worse when fighting mages)  TL;DR: This game is great, but steel yourself if you have to play games on Hard. The combat bugs are manageable on Normal, however. If you can deal with the bugs and crashes (maybe you won't crash as often as I did), then this game is fantastic, in my opinion. I hope you enjoy it if you do decide to pick it up! :)

The world of the Witcher is unlike anything I've ever played. If you were to compare Skyrim to Lord of the Rings, then The Witcher would be Game of Thrones. Here, you aren't the chosen one. You're just a man (mutant) on a simple revenge quest living and fratranizing with the filth of the city. Although- the choices you make definately make a difference in the world and come to bite you in the ♥♥♥ later. There's no hand holding in The Witcher. No obvious choices either. Each have concequences.   Highly reccomend this game. 10/10.

First off; the bad.  1) The combat's a bit clunky.   2) There's lots of story. I mean lots and lots and lots of story. So many quests and directions, you have to just pick a random quest off your list and go to the next objective. A bit disorienting sometimes.  3) Open-world, but not quite. The game is split into chapters, and once out of said chapter, you can't go back. Except that some quests span multiple chapters. It can get confusing.   4) It's a bit buggy and can therefore crash often. But saves aren't restricted. Save often.   The good: 1) The combat is clunky, but that makes it pretty easy to master. About three seconds into a fight, I can tell which way it's going to go -- whether I'm going to survive, and whether I need to adapt.  2) There's lots and lots of story. You get dropped into the middle of this man's life; trying to figure out both his past and determining his future. Your actions have consequences, your choices have outcomes. It's horribly confusing and disorienting sometimes; but if you jump in with both feet you'll find yourself mesmerized and unable to put it down.   3) Atmospheric as ♥♥♥♥. People have schedules and routes. Guards follow a route at night, townspeople spend their days inside at work, go to the bar afterwards, and to their homes after that. People huddle under rooves and complain about the rain as it pours. Some disapprove of your weapons, others thank you for your help as you pass. Monsters become more aggressive & numerous at night. Guards tell you you're weird for being out so late.   4) Trophy system. Certain monsters are legendary in areas and fetch a high price. If you manage to down it, people want proof. You carry the head with you until turning it in to claim your reward.   Honorable mentions: 1) Yes, you can have sex with many women. Yes, you get to collect cards from encounters. There is a romance system (a bit shallow, but still there), I quite like it. It blends in very well with Geralt's life and the game in general. Also, you can choose a permanent gf that carries over into next game.  2) Mods. Bugfixes, UI overhauls, even one to fix the distasteful combat system (I myself dont' mind it, but many do). Also, you can update the textures and even introduce and ENB to update the look some.   9.5/10 I LOVE this game. I can't wait to finish it and see what the next game will show me. I'll probably play through both of these games again before Wild Hunt comes out. If you're thinking about getting this game but are unsure, give it a try. You COULD watch a YT video summarizing the first game, but wouldn't playing it for yourself be better?

Controversal and moral topics discussed, your decisions questioned.  You play as Geralt of Rivia, a witcher - a professional monster slayer for hire. But nothing is as simple as that. Even though you are a monster slayer, whose job is to protect humans (and non-humans), there are those who have plans of their own for the future of the kingdom. The most of the story is set in Vizima, one of the towns in the kingdom of Temeria, but you'll be traveling to some other unique places as you progress. Captivating, non-linear story and a lot of side quests, relatively big and open-world search and traveling will keep you busy for a while.  As for the gameplay itself, you will be facing a lot of different opponents and all of them will require a different approach to combat and different strategies in order to be beaten (especially bosses). You wield swords - steel and silver ones. The first is used against non-monster creatures while the latter becomes useful against abominations. You utilize the mastery of swordmanship utmost and different styles/stances to prevail in all situtations and conflicts. You also possess a certain amount of knowledge about magic as you are able to cast Witcher Signs which are classified as simple magic, but they sure come in handy nonetheless. A witcher is also a master of alchemy. You're able to brew a variety of potions in order to enhance your abilities and ensure dominance in combat. (Many other interesting / optional stuff is available in the game, too. Some of those would be: Mini-games, crafting, collecting, enchanting, love, etc.)  As for the graphics, the game looks relatively out-dated, but don't let that turn you away from this amazing piece of software. The game is rather breathtaking at times considering the year of it's release date.  If you like RPG games with great story, character development, unique combat (not everyone will like this, but you can get used to it rather fast - just be patient) and all of that while while experiencing a great adventure, you should give this game a try. You won't regret it.

First thing you need to know: If you consider yourself an RPG fan at all, get The Witcher. Heck, if you're a fan of fantasy in general, get The Witcher.   TL;DR: People say this game is unrefined and awkward, and they're sort of right, but the real reason to play this game is the story. Let me make clear that this game has THE BEST story I've ever seen in a game. It loses a bit of steam around chapter 2, but afterward it just keeps getting better. How many games have you finished, only to think afterward, 'the game was good, but the ending was kind of disappointing'? How many have you finished and thought, 'What an interesting, satisfying ending'? Probably almost none. Kudos to The Witcher for providing a personal, self-contained story with an incredible twist at the end that's not in any way sequel-bait. Although believe me, you'll definitely want to play the sequel.   Actual review:  The combat may be an acquired taste, and it may not have the same level of exploration as something like Skyrim, but as a story,'The Witcher is the best I've seen in any game. The setting is somewhat archetypical, filled with nature-loving elves with pointy ears and dwarves with huge beards and a lust for gold--pretty much the epitome of a stereotypical fantasy world. It even borrows things from the classic King Arthur legends. But it's the perfect setting for its personal, multi-faceted, complex narrative, and never ceases to be interesting.   If you've played Mass Effect, you'll be familiar with the game's dialogue system. Simmilar to those games, too, The Witcher has something of a moral choice system, only the choice system in The Witcher is better in almost every way. The choices don't pop up every 5 minutes like they do in Mass Effect, but when they do, they make you think. Hard. None of this is like 'press A to be good, B to be a jerk'-- everything is ambiguous and there are always good reasons to make either choice.   The way the quests are set up is interesting, too, because almost every quest ties back into another one in some way. What may at first seem like an unimportant side mission may later prove to play an integral part in the main story. It's an organic experience I haven't found anywhere else.   While the graphics are very dated, and probably weren't even that impressive when it first came out, the art style is beautiful and unique. Every loading screen, and some occasional cutscenes, have beautiful still pictures that look like they were oil-painted. It contrasts with the actual game, but still captures the overall feel. The music is great, too, and very unique, often using instruments I don't even know the name of.   The game's weak point is of course the combat. The idea is to click the mouse at exactly the right time to chain attacks together, and it's very easy to click at the wrong time and stop attacking without even realising it. Also, one mouse click usually results in several sword swings, which ends up making things feel unresponsive. It took me a couple hours to really 'get' it, but once I did it actually got pretty fun. The combat is VERY hard at times, but towards the end when Geralt has levelled up a lot, it actually gets too easy. The final mission was probably the easiest; I only remember dying there once or twice.   Bottom line is, if you're looking for a mature, story-driven RPG, The Witcher is as good as it gets. Except for The Witcher 2, of course. But that, as good ol' Dandelion would say, is another story.

Sometimes you're going the right way, through a blessed shortcut you'll eventually find, but the map points the other way, and if you follow it, you'll just go the longest way possible. It's just as if the dev wanted us to roam forever in this open, open, really wide opened world, and I do believ most people that dropped out the game, did it during the 2nd/3rd chapter, the ones when this happened really often.  3/10  Inconsistency - So, you'll have areas with 2/3 enemies once in a while, then suddenly they're in gangs of 20, and then there's no enemies whastoever, it does not increase with the progression of the history. nope . The bosses feel the same way. You have a boss that you have to kill a particular way, and that actually gives you some challenge, then the next is killed with 2/3 attacks, then the next takes you lots of effort, and it goes on pretty much like this. GAMEPLAY:  A cracking RPG with lots of side quests and things to do, it's not all just fighting big scary monsters, you can go from playing poker to picking on all the fat people in taverns, an easy to use inventory system and absolutely fantastic encyclopedia of everything, everyplace and everyone you meet, which is truly useful to the game and immersing the player into the world of The Witcher. At points it can seem as though you are wandering for far too long, running around the place getting bits and bobs.. this is because the game is without a fast track system.. although i don't mind that, for me it made me impatient to go to the next chapter due to the fact i had walked the same routes 15 times and just wanted to do something else  COMBAT:  Easy to Pick up and easy to master, at times the motion of clicking your mouse button can seem repetitive BUT the animations for combat are always fresh and the further into the game you go the better they get, with different styles of attack for different enemy types you will be having to plan out your attacks and prepare for battles ahead using potions, bombs and the correct sword, there is more than enough to keep you on your toes. Sometimes moving Geralt mid combat can be clunky but this is only a minor issue  VISUALS:  My computer isn't the best and couldn't run this on high.. but that's my computer i imagine most would be able to.. even with my settings on medium The Witcher was a beautiful game with new and interesting locations varying from bright and colourful to dark and ominous. The art and design gone into all the creatures and landscapes is unique and the cards which i can only call... Sexy Souvenirs... are something at first you giggle at but when you actually look at them with an appreciation, you'll see they are beautifully drawn.  AUDIO:  The music used in the witcher during peaceful times, is always tranquil and feels very medieval/rennaisance, when it all hits the fan and theres monsters left, right and centre, the heavy rockier combat music is a delight at times and can sometimes really insue a panic on the player. Characters dialog is also very well delivered with Geralt's voice always calm and steely, an Evil sorcerer with an almost James Earl Jones voice. Monsters grunts and grumbles however aren't always as unique with most 4 footed creatures roaring and most 2 legged floaty ones, screeching.  STORY:   The Story stayed very consistent in it's delivery and pace always having an air of mystery to it and always keeping the player entertained, at certain points it had an almost Film Noire vibe in a medieval backdrop which i found quite refreshing. At times you felt quite attached to characters and feared whether your actions had consequences on the characters... which i can only hold to good character development created by the script. The decisions you make in the game can affect how it all ends... (so i believe... i've only played it once)   RATING:  I give 'The Witcher' 8 out of 10 as i believe there is always room for improvement.. but more because the lengthy walking, at times, slowed the pace of the game for me and took me out of immersion

Adapted from the Polish folklore and fantasy novel series, comes the tale of Geralt of Rivia, The Witcher. In this game you'll be playing as Geralt who is a 'Witcher', a monster slayer. This game takes place after the novel, 'The Last Wish', and has Geralt hunting down a notorious gang called 'Salamandra' as he uncovers secrets about the world while learning about himself and his past. The game shares the same engine as Mass Effect 1, and concentrates highly on conversations and use of skills. You'll be using sword-styles to fight groups, fast enemies, or big enemies. The quest log provided takes a small amount of fiddling with, but is no more difficult to track quests and display your destinations as it is in Skyrim. Alchemy is entertaining to mess with, creating actually useful items and potions made from things you've found or plants you've picked.  The skill tree gets pretty in depth as you create what kind of Witcher Geralt will become and what skills he will have. Will he be an all out brawler who's strength increases as he drinks ale? Or will he be a cunning mage? Howabout a deft swordsman with many trades? You decide. Looting is also present in The Witcher, so if you're a fan of perusing cubbords, pantries, and entire houses and dungeons of any and all possible treasure you'll be a happy camper in the world of The Witcher. Camera options are interesting, as you have the choice to play over-the-shoulder like many third person games, or have a top-down isometric view where you point and click Geralt's every move. The music in The Witcher is okay, nothing really memorable, but not irritating or too repetitive.  All in all The Witcher is a pretty entertaining adventure. Its easy to play it and feel similarities to Dragon Age, maybe, but in all its pretty unique. My only gripes would be that I wished there was a little more to the combat, (it does get a little repetitive) and that the voice acting was a little bit better. Some children shouldn't sound like mature adults, and some npcs get a little awkward at times. Also, if older tech is a deal-breaker for you than this may not be the game for you. There is a level of forgiveness here you'll have to have while playing, as the game is pretty dated looking. Released in 2007, its practically the quality of a PlayStation 2 game rather than a title that compares with most games of 2007 during the HD gaming revolution period. It would have been nice if there was some sort of Fast Travel, even though the maps aren't TOO big, there are times when quests require you to run back and forth in places like the Outskirts of Vizina? (sp?) where you run back and forth across the entire map to NPCs. But its not too hard to deal with since you often find items running back and forth. Anything odd, glitchy, or awkward isn't usually a bad thing, and sometimes adds some hilarity to the mix. Its one of those games where anything thats not that great can be funny.  Don't let the 'Enhanced Edition' name fool you, there's a reason why thats the only version on Steam. The original game was very terrible, so the 'Enhanced Edition' made it actually enjoyable. Look for a list of changes from the original to the Enhanced Edition on wiki, its quite amazing.  If graphics and older tech don't matter to you and you're looking for something new in this genre then you should totally give this game a try. ESPECIALLY if you're planning on playing The Witcher 2 and 3.  +Unique Story +Skill Tree +Geralt is a badass +Quest Log +Alchemy  -Voice Acting -No fast travel -Very simple graphics for a 2007 game  I give it an honest 7.5/10

I am one of those weirdos that actually enjoyed the first Witcher game more than the second (with the third being the best overall). This game is certainly less polished than the sequel, but it feels bigger thanks to the huge number of sidequests and monster hunts.   Story is one of the big selling points for me; the core story avoids the political tomfoolery that punctuated a lot of Witcher 2's story beats and instead tells a simple tale of Geralt's hunt for some stolen Witcher formulas that eventually leads him into the middle of a war between the Scoia'tael and the Order of the Flaming Rose. Two things work in the first game's favour here; as well as the main story there's a large amount of sidequests that expand on the world and often include some interesting situations such as curing/killing a werewolf or battling a Striga. What's interesting is that many of the quests have alternate routes, and failing to investigate and learn about the monsters you're fighting can lead to extra information being lost.   The second thing in its favour, and something that I sorely missed in the sequel, is a pure neutral path. With virtually all of the major decisions in the game you can just refuse to pick a side and let the two sides to the war kill each other, only getting involved when thing's get personal.   There's also a fair bit of grinding and tons of weapons and other things to find; it's the kind of thing that will annoy many players, but for someone like me it just made the game even more alluring. Combat is fairly hit and miss though, but the flow and the expanding animations that come as you level up helped stave of boredom.   I personally love this game, but if you're looking to give it a go after playing the second or third games you'd better be prepared for a real rough-around-the-edges (to be honest, it's rough round the middle bits too) experience that very much feels like a game rather than an experience, but if you can persevere the world-building and storyline can more than make up for its shortcomings.

Where this game really shines though is the story, and the choices you're given along the way. I felt much more invested in Geralt of Rivia, and had a sense that my in-game actions actually had consequences. In a lot of games I find myself tuning out during cutscenes, and just wanting to get back to the action, but The Witcher kept me engaged til the end.  My biggest criticism is probably combat, which is pretty simplistic, and can thus be a little boring at times. Apart from deciding which sword and combat style to use, there's not much to it - just click to attack, then wait til the right time to attack again.  Ultimately though, this isn't a huge issue, as the richness of the world and narrative more than makes up for it.  I should also mention that this game allows you to try and get laid lots, which no doubt many will enjoy... :)

The look and feel are classic Witcher. It has the atmosphere, characters and lore that you want in a game of this kind. I appreciated the fact that inventory was limited, too often in games you end up with page after page of junk you just hang onto out of habit, here you choose carefully or sell it. The potion brewing is a crucial element, if you pay attention to it you can get some serious buffs etc, if you don't, you're gonna get seriously familiar with the combat mechanic and probably have a bad time.   Combat itself is interesting. It's almost part QTE where you must time your strikes precisely, and part puzzle, where choosing the right setup will make a big difference. Where it suffers is movement. You can see what they were trying to do, the move set and style of the character are straight out of a classic sword fighting movie. Unfortunately it's a bit too clunky to make it work fluently much of the time. Fighting mobs is a gamble even if your set up is good as you can easily get cornered and destroyed in short order, particularly in mobs with mixed fighting styles.   I personally found quest management frustrating at first, it's managed almost like the books the games are based on. One chapter flows into the next and quite often a quest is left hanging until you can pick it up again later. It's an interesting approach but until you familiarise yourself with the system it can be overwhelming, with tons of half finished threads you have to wade through to find the stuff that's relevant. I'd advise anyone playing this first time to tinker with this until you're happy, It *is* very configurable.  The only other gripe I have is one that is likely to trip you up again and again. Invisible walls. This is hands down the most frustrating part of the game as you can do nothing about it. Everything else is a learning process or something you can adapt to. Not this. All I can say is be aware of it and choose your fights carefully.  Overall, despite the gripes I find it hard to really criticise this game. It's got everything you want in a solid RPG. Interesting characters, good writing, atmospheric locations, decisions that make a difference (Triss is no longer talking to me....) and more. It's believable, which is rare for any game. The use of old myths and folklore give you a real sense that it might have actually happened in ages past. The vast majority of encounters are embedded in this world view, giving them a reason to exist, rather than just an endless series of random encounters to keep you busy. It's very, very clever and not one you want to miss.

Most of these are mostly mundane, are highly optional to your playstyle. YOU, yes you, can essentially go by two different play styles from certain decisions you can make in the game. Slayer, you side with humans in every case, you were made to protect people from the threat of magical entities. Sympathizer you side with magical entities that might be innocent of their crimes. Most of which border on the grey territory of morality. Though neutrality is an option, it hinders you in the later stages of the game. Gameplay at times will either be frustrating do to the timing mechanism, and the constant enemies who will constantly appear in the same places you may have visited before will lose any thrill you might have of the combat system very soon.  Do I recommend playing this game? yes I do, as much of the frustration, and wrath I get in this game comes from being a result oriented player, being impatient with the time needed to do every quest. That is me, and my opinion, I will state on my first play it great, second not so much. One thing also hinders newer players from playing this game, none of the actions you do in this game translate over to the second game. Except are extremely left light in their reference of what really happened. Also as a warning this was made by Konami when they were still decent.

I wanted to like this game, I really did. But in the end the experience was more frustrating than enjoyable. There are plenty of reviews talking about the setting and what's great, and there are good things in this game, but here are the things that kept bugging me.  - The environments are huge, but for no reason. There is almost nothing to explore. And because everything is always at opposite ends of the map, you end up running back and forth all the time, fighting lots and lots of irritating low-level enemies on the way. - The fighting system seems interesting but ultimately provides little depth. It's way too clumsy to just be enjoyable in an action-rpg sense, and too inconsequential to be interesting to master. Bombs are completely unnecessary, you can upgrade weapons, but you end up getting much better weapons from quests, and magic has very little use except for two spells, and so on... - Fights are either stupidly hard or incredibly easy. You either kill the foes easily or you're cornered by a group that spams you with stunning/blinding/something attacks that leave you motionless for several seconds.  - Characters always end conversations before you're fully done. Rather than allowing you to consistently explore all conversation options and then quit, they end it for you and walk away. That means you may miss an important conversation option and aimlessly wander about looking for the next trigger to continue a quest. - Some conversation options only appear once. For example, I tried to play dice with one of the characters. But when I got to the option I wanted to first save the game, so selected 'not now', quit the conversation and saved. But after declining once, I never had another chance to start a conversation with the character again, and couldn't finish the quest as a result. - Conversations are sometimes random. A character may offer you a product or service in exchange for something else. If you don't happen have what they want on you, you're out of luck since this character may never make you the same offer again. I understand this is more realistic, but this simply doesn't work in a game. - Conversations are out of order. Things you can't possibly know yet turn up in conversation. It's confusing. - the map marker sometimes isn't helpful at all. For example, you may need to talk to someone, and the map marker will point the character's house. But the NPC will wander about the city rather than be at home, and they're sometimes impossible to find. That would be ok if it was to make things more realistic, and if you could maybe ask other NPC's where you can find the character. But at the same time, the map marker will always show up whether you've explored that part of the map or not. So if you're supposed to get something out of a grave, you'll know exactly where it is whether you've been there before or not. So the argument that it's for realism doesn't really apply. - The whole sex-card thing is just plain weird. I don't have an issue with sex in games, but the over-abundance of naked female foes and making sex a collectable ... seriously? It's a strange contrast to the otherwise mature themes of the game.  Anyway, I did finish the game, and there were fun parts. Particularly the last act picked up considerably, mostly because the maps were a bit tighter and there was less back and forth. But in the end I don't think it's nearly as good as people were making it out to be. It's ambitious, but ultimately flawed.
