This game has interesting ideas that built the fundemental models the Witcher sequels use, however it ultimately falls short as a standalone title. The story is the main drive of the game yet it can become very uninteresting very quickly unless you pay attention to every little detail and constantly check your journal for background information on characters and quests. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it ends up making you lose motivation to continue if you don't absolutely pay attention to what each character interaction entails. Completing quests, on the other hand, essentially boils down to you running from one end of the mostly boring enviroments to the other with the occasional sprinkles of combat in between. Even when the game introduces detective elements to the quests, they still feel like a chore and yield no substantial outcomes or rewards for your efforts; most of the time, they lead you to track a second or third person.  As for the combat, it feels very bland. The only thing making it different from a point-and-click mini-game is the alchemical preparations that can be carried out before each battle. But even that is something most people will choose to avoid since it is largely unnecessary at lower difficulty levels. My biggest complaint of all, however, is that at no point in the game do you feel like you have made significant progress as a player or as the character. There is no skill for you to master as a player as there is in other RPGs such as Dark Souls. And after 16 hours into this game, I also feel as though Geralt was the same as he was during his first fight (albeit with a few more spells).   Apart from the initial sparks of interest in the story, this game offered little of its own to compel me to continue my adventure. So, unless your intention is to learn how the Witcher games evolved as a series, you will be just fine skipping this title and reading up the story online to play the sequels.

Horrible game with lots of unfulfilled promise.   This is a bad game with bad design and worse mechanics.   My #1 complaint with this game is how it promises a certain style of play, and then completely fails to live up to that promise. What am I talking about? Specifically, how the game promises that 'Witchers fight enemies on their terms,' but then every major fight in the game is a total surprise after a cut-scene, so you, the player, have no time to consume potions and 'prepare' for the battle like a proper Witcher.   Witchers are supposed to 'prepare' for fights; they're all about potions and prep, right? Well, not once you actually start playing the game. Forget that. Instead, you're stuck with long, dailog-heavy cut-scenes that you can't click-through, and then you're thrust into battle with enemies standing immediately next to you, getting free shots at you before you can even draw your sword. Where's the preparation aspect? What use are potions if you can only manage to drink a single one while your enemies beat on you at the start of a fight and knock your health down? It's a catch-22 at that point: do I risk drinking a potion and getting my health knocked down, or do I try and fight with no potions and die that way instead? Either way, you're going to get your butt handed to you, so then you'll have to reload a save, which will be BEFORE the long cut-scene, so now you're going to have to sit through the dialog AGAIN. Rinse, repeat... ugh. Not worth it.   And potions... don't get me started. What should have been a very awesome aspect to this game is totally butchered in its execution.   The Witcher's inventory is VERY limited, and potions are pretty much a rare commodity to be hoarded and used only at the proper moment before battle. But there's a myriad of problems with that idea, and the way the designers implemented this game, it just doesn't work.   For starters, the potions don't tell you how long they last, so you have no idea when you start playing if a potion lasts 8 hours or 20 minutes. Knowing this information would go a long way toward deciding WHEN to consume a potion. Once you use a potion and see how long it lasts, YOU, the player, are forced to remember this information as you play, instead of it being a part of the metadata that is should be easily accessible in the potions section of the journal (thanks, but I think my character should know that information, not me). The Witcher is billed as a monster-hunter who relies heavily on his knowledge of his enemies to fight them in situations that are advantageous to the Witcher. You would think, then, that the Witcher would know the duration of his own potions.   Second, unless you're clairvoyant, or have already played through the game in its entirety, you have no idea exactly when is a good time to consume a potion. And if a potion lasts, say, 20 minutes, odds are you're going to waste a huge chunk of that time in stupid cut-scenes...  On top of all of this, the fighting mechanics are just clunky and unresponsive. This is, quite literally, the clunkiest fighting style I've ever seen in a video game. It's aggravating. It's like a cross between Neverwinter Nights and whack-a-mole. It would have been better if the designers would have just opted for a point-and-click-autoattack approach like NWN or some other DnD game. Instead, they want you to 'chain' attacks together but clicking 'only when they want you to click', but when a half-dozen bad guys are beating on your butt after a cut-scene, that sort of thing just doesn't work. Players reflexes and instincts are basically way too fast for this slow interface and sluggish fighting style. Either autoattack and let the player choose targets, or let the player really control Geralt and fight the enemies.   And the cut-scenes. My gosh, the cut-scenes. So. Many. Cut. Scenes. You can't even take a short trip through the sewer to kill a dumb bird without fifty cut-scenes completely killing your momentum. It's beyond aggravating.   I really, really wanted to like this game when it came out years ago, but I couldn't suffer it beyond Vizima. Years later I tried again, downloading off Steam, and I can't even make it out of the Detective's house. This game is insufferable. I'm sure there's a good idea in here, but the execution is just terrible.   Plain and simple: playing this game is no fun.

I feel fairly conflicted about The Witcher. On the one hand, it starts off great, gives you an interesting introduction that sets up a story that promises intrigue and twists. You get to the first major chapter and there's plenty to do, atmosphere, a feeling of forboding, enemies that make you think twice about running in unprepared, it all just seems great and deadly and complex at the start. Then you get to Chapter II, for the first half, it's the same sense of wonder and excitement and enjoyment, you're doing all the quests and are still heavily invested in the plot. Then you reach the second half of Chapter II, you realize the majority of the sidequests are pointless and not worth doing, most of the potions aren't worth using even on the harder difficulty, the combat is just clicking and it will never be more than that, the story is taking ages to progress and most of the dialogue just isn't interesting. Your love interests are dull and full of typical cliched writing. Then you finish, after rushing through the rest of the game hoping to get through the drudgery, and with a disappointing ending and a feeling of having done more work than play, you realize that this game just isn't all that great. The Witcher II is an amazing game, but it's not really worth playing The Witcher I, it's just a dreary prototype for a much better game.

Steam tells me I have 8 friends who played this game. I feel deeply sorry for them.   If video games were to be evaluated in a similar manner to that of a writing assignment, The Witcher would go straight in the 'fail' pile like a paper whose handwriting is so illegible that deigning to read it would be a fool's errand. While the loading screens offer promise of lush, detailed and open environments, the game itself launches with a 10-odd-minute cutscene establishing the character, Geralt of Riviera. What this sequence conveys is rather simple: CD Projekt Red created the coolest character to star in a video game ever (if you're 12), and they want to spend the amount of time in your life it would take to cook and serve a meal to yourself before any gameplay starts expressing as much.   The optimization is so ♥♥♥♥-poor that if you aren't the kind of person who makes an entire hobby out of building computers that play video games rather than just playing video games yourself, you'll be met with a message upon trying to launch the game that system requirements are not met. (Before any confusion, I'll take time to note here that my system runs Dark Souls in 720p with nary a hitch.) Waiting for the launcher to execute after reading this message is another fool's errand; it will not, until a line of code bypassing this check is added in the properties of a shortcut to the executable. What a load of ♥♥♥♥.   Interpreting this message as that of a game with some real muscle behind it, I am side-swiped by a notion of profound disappointment--let's call it 'what the ♥♥♥♥ is this'-ness--when I arrive in-game to find myself in a world of N64-grade textures, populated by PS2-grade character models (one of whom, amid a scraggly lot of dreary-looking Tolkien caricatures, more closely resembles a Maxim pin-up with more body mass in her ♥♥♥♥ than in all the rest of her put together), whose uncanny animations jerk and stutter at an unstable framerate. Recoiling in horror from this mannequin-acted softcore porno-opera perverted from the base stipulations for a high fantasy backdrop (there's swords and wizards and ♥♥♥♥), I can scarcely take a step backwards before the game wrests control to turn me back around like a child being led from the grown-ups table.   Combat comes in a choice of two formats: overhead point-and-click Diablo style, or over-the-shoulder with WASD controls. I suppose there is also the option to play overhead with the WASD controls, but it's rather awful and seems provided as an afterthought. The meat of the aforementioned combat is comprised of running up to a bad guy after having drawn your sword and mash-clicking your left mouse button, performing skillful fencing maneuvers in-game and Tourettes-spazzing on your mouse in real life while your enemy stands and behaves just as he did before you got there. This may be a result of the game failing to behave as it should. After all, I am playing on a laptop, and it is terribly, terribly optimized.   Attempting this sequence twice was all I could stomach before returning to Steam and requesting refund for my $1.50 purchase. I could buy a Coke with that. With the witcher 3 only a few months away and looking awesome, i thought i would go back and play the witcher 1 and 2 and prepare myself for the 3rd, familiarising myself with the story.   With so many people praising how good the first game is, claiming it is even one of the best rpg's people have played ever i was excited, but it all changed after i finally booted up the game and started playing.   The first thing you'll notice is how dated the game looks and feels, despite being a game that is relatively old now (released in 2008) the game just looks like an upscaled ps2 or original xbox title, the textures are poor, the animations are pretty clunky and the character models just look stiff and emotionless, but i do have to say the general atmosphere is fantastic and does make you feel like you are in a gritty world with its dark art style. The combat i felt was pretty unsatisfying either, all it requires is you click the left mouse button in sync with the flame icon that pops up for you to continue the combo, and you will often have to change between 3 stances, one stance that is for big slow opponents, one that is for smaller quicker opponents and one that is for when you are surrounded by a group. There is also magic spells you can use but they just feel tacked on and not special.  The problem is that the game is boring, i managed to get through the extremely slow beginning but even after that the game doesnt do enough to keep you interested. Ive read a lot of people who say that despite the slow start the game opens up after chapter 3, but thats the problem, i shouldnt have to put in 20 hours before a games story begins to open up, its just not fun. There are way too many fetch quests that require you to run from one side of the map to other at least 5 times talking to NPC's that by the end it you will be to exhausted to care. I am roughly 10 hours in and the game has felt like a chore and i think its time i pull the pin, i am just not pulled into the world or the character.   I thought i could power through the game for the story but its just not fun or exciting enough for me to do so, if you like doing fetch quests, backtracking and heaps of dialogue then maybe this game is for you. I would personally think its better to not waste your time and jump straight into the Witcher 2, from what i have read not playing the first game doesnt really impact on what happens in the 2nd game. I kept hearing about The Witcher and how unique it was, how much its influenced video game design, and how much I should play it. Well, I've played it, but I can't seem to get myself to finish it.  The first problem I encountered was with the boss monster at the end of Chapter One. Up until this point, the game had taught me that - as a monster hunter - monsters needed to be studied before you killed them. You had to buy a book, read about the monster in question, and prepare necessary potions or oils (monster poison). I felt like an authentic monster hunter.  Then the first boss fight happened.  The books I had read on it said that I'd have to answer a riddle before fighting it. That it would be vulnerable if I answered correctly. I had time to prepare before beginning my assault on the forces who were behind its summoning. Then I was interrupted rather abruptly by some cut-scene dialogue where I was faced with some pretty boring black/white morality decisions. And then the boss appeared and stunned me and hit me until I died. Total fight time: roughly 15 seconds. So, I loaded my previous save, before the dialogue, and tried again. I lasted 20 seconds this time, though again, most of it was spent stunned.  At this point I checked the internet for some advice. All of the advice consisted of exploiting a terrain feature and using a certain weapon oil to kill it from safety. So I tried again. This time, I made some oils, coated my weapon, drank a couple of buff potions, and then proceeded with the dialogue. When the fight started, all of my potion effects were removed. So I died again. Load, die, load, die, load, die. Eventually I beat the boss by waiting until the fight started and then applying my oil and drinking my potions. Though this resulted in my death the first few attempts (the animations are painfully elaborate.)  This is not what the game had trained me to do. There was no preparation necessary. There was no riddle. There was no warning at all. Completely ruined the immersion for me.  Chapter two was full of women offerring to have sex with the protagonist in exchange for laughably easy item drops or mini-quests. Some investigation into the wiki revealed that there were no romance options for these encounters, and no effect on either of the two main romance options. At one point, an anatomically-correct and completely nude dryad offers to have sex with me in exchange for a single wolf pelt, which wolves have a 100% chance of dropping. There were wolves not 5 seconds away from the dryad.  As a male gamer who is no longer 13 years old, I was pretty disappointed by this behavior. The game is laughable, the plot predictable, the mechanics repetitive, and the mysogyny made me feel incredibly uncomfortable.
